message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Large language models empowered agent-based modeling and simulation: a survey and perspectives
Paper Abstract: Abstract Agent-based modeling and simulation have evolved as a powerful tool for modeling complex systems, offering insights into emergent behaviors and interactions among diverse agents. Recently, integrating large language models into agent-based modeling and simulation presents a promising avenue for enhancing simulation capabilities. This paper surveys the landscape of utilizing large language models in agent-based modeling and simulation, discussing their challenges and promising future directions. In this survey, since this is an interdisciplinary field, we first introduce the background of agent-based modeling and simulation and large language model-empowered agents. We then discuss the motivation for applying large language models to agent-based simulation and systematically analyze the challenges in environment perception, human alignment, action generation, and evaluation. Most importantly, we provide a comprehensive overview of the recent works of large language model-empowered agent-based modeling and simulation in multiple scenarios, which can be divided into four domains: cyber, physical, social, and hybrid, covering simulation of both real-world and virtual environments, and how these works address the above challenges. Finally, since this area is new and quickly evolving, we discuss the open problems and promising future directions. We summarize the representative papers along with their code repositories in https://github.com/tsinghua-fib-lab/LLM-Agent-Based-Modeling-and-Simulation .
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Emergent behavior"

Links: [{"title":"Emergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergence"},{"title":"Emergent behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Emergent_behavior&redirect=no"},{"title":"Emergent gameplay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergent_gameplay"},{"title":"Emergent algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergent_algorithm"},{"title":"Flocking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flocking"},{"title":"Behavior tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behaviour_tree"}]

Based on the search results, here's what emergent behavior is:

## Definition

An emergent behavior of a physical system is a qualitative property that can only occur in the limit that the number of microscopic constituents tends to infinity.

## Key Characteristics

An emergent algorithm implements a set of simple building block behaviors that when combined exhibit more complex behaviors. In simpler terms, emergent behavior occurs when simple individual rules or components interact to create complex, unexpected patterns.

## Real-World Examples

One classic example is flocking, an emergent behaviour governed by local rules that are followed by individuals and does not involve any central coordination. Individual birds follow simple local rules, yet together they create the complex, coordinated patterns seen in bird murmurations.

Other examples of emergent algorithms and models include cellular automata, artificial neural networks and swarm intelligence systems (ant colony optimization, bees algorithm, etc.).

## In Technology and Games

Emergent gameplay refers to complex situations in video games, board games, or role-playing games that emerge from the interaction of relatively simple game mechanics. Game designers often create simple rules that lead to unpredictable and creative player behaviors they didn't explicitly program.

Here are the results for "Computer simulation":

## Definition
Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.(no content)By changing variables in the simulation, predictions may be made about the behaviour of the system.

## Applications
Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics (computational physics), astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.(no content)It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.

## History
Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Types of Simulations
A continuous dynamic simulation performs numerical solution of differential-algebraic equations or differential equations (either partial or ordinary). Periodically, the simulation program solves all the equations and uses the numbers to change the state and output of the simulation. Applications include flight simulators, construction and management simulation games, chemical process modeling, and simulations of electrical circuits.

I've successfully completed a web search for "Complex systems." Here are the key findings:

## Definition

A complex system is a system composed of many components that interact with one another.(no content)The term complex systems often refers to the study of complex systems, which is an approach to science that investigates how relationships between a system's parts give rise to its collective behaviors and how the system interacts and forms relationships with its environment.

## Key Characteristics

Systems that are "complex" have distinct properties that arise from these relationships, such as nonlinearity, emergence, spontaneous order, adaptation, and feedback loops, among others. Additionally, the behavior of a complex system is intrinsically difficult to model due to the dependencies, competitions, relationships, and other types of interactions between their parts or between a given system and its environment.

## Examples

Examples of complex systems are Earth's global climate, organisms, the human brain, infrastructure such as power grid, transportation or communication systems, complex software and electronic systems, social and economic organizations (like cities), an ecosystem, a living cell, and, ultimately, for some authors, the entire universe.

## Research Approach

The study of complex systems regards collective, or system-wide, behaviors as the fundamental object of study; for this reason, complex systems can be understood as an alternative paradigm to reductionism, which attempts to explain systems in terms of their constituent parts and the individual interactions between them.

Systems that are "complex" have distinct properties that arise from these relationships, such as nonlinearity, emergence, spontaneous order, adaptation, and feedback loops, among others. Additionally, the behavior of a complex system is intrinsically difficult to model due to the dependencies, competitions, relationships, and other types of interactions between their parts or between a given system and its environment.

## Examples

Examples of complex systems are Earth's global climate, organisms, the human brain, infrastructure such as power grid, transportation or communication systems, complex software and electronic systems, social and economic organizations (like cities), an ecosystem, a living cell, and, ultimately, for some authors, the entire universe.

## Research Approach

The study of complex systems regards collective, or system-wide, behaviors as the fundamental object of study; for this reason, complex systems can be understood as an alternative paradigm to reductionism, which attempts to explain systems in terms of their constituent parts and the individual interactions between them.

Here are the search results for "Large language models":

## Overview

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Capabilities and Structure

These models consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.(no content)LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

## Limitations

These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

Web search results for query: "Agent-based model"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agent-based modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Agent-based_modeling&redirect=no"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Sugarscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarscape"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about agent-based models:

## Definition

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.(no content)It combines elements of game theory, complex systems, emergence, computational sociology, multi-agent systems, and evolutionary programming.

## Key Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified atvarious scales (typically referred to as agent-granularity); (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

## How They Work

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.(no content)Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena. The process is one of emergence, which some express as "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts". In other words, higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

## Historical Development

The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

## Applications

ABMs are used in many scientific domains including biology, ecology and social science. They have also been applied to areas such as economics, transportation, and ecological modeling.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about artificial intelligence agents:

## What is an AI Agent?

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Types of AI Agents

**Agentic AI (Modern AI Agents):**
In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems or agentic AI) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.

**Autonomous Agents:**
An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.

**Embodied Agents:**
In artificial intelligence, an embodied agent, also sometimes referred to as an interface agent, is an intelligent agent that interacts with the environment through a physical body within that environment.

## Complexity Range

Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex. A basic thermostat or control system is considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria—such as a firm, a state, or a biome.

## Modern Applications

A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request. Prominent examples include Devin AI, AutoGPT, and SIMA.(no content)Further examples of agents released since 2025 include OpenAI Operator, ChatGPT Deep Research, Manus, Quark (based on Qwen), AutoGLM Rumination, and Coze (by ByteDance).

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about artificial intelligence agents:

## What is an AI Agent?

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Types of AI Agents

**Agentic AI (Modern AI Agents):**
In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems or agentic AI) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.

**Autonomous Agents:**
An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.

**Embodied Agents:**
In artificial intelligence, an embodied agent, also sometimes referred to as an interface agent, is an intelligent agent that interacts with the environment through a physical body within that environment.

## Complexity Range

Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex. A basic thermostat or control system is considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria—such as a firm, a state, or a biome.

## Modern Applications

A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request. Prominent examples include Devin AI, AutoGPT, and SIMA.(no content)Further examples of agents released since 2025 include OpenAI Operator, ChatGPT Deep Research, Manus, Quark (based on Qwen), AutoGLM Rumination, and Coze (by ByteDance).

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! I have successfully completed all tasks. Here's a summary:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** This paper is classified as a **survey** - it comprehensively reviews the landscape of large language model integration in agent-based modeling and simulation.

**Key Entities Extracted:** I identified and documented 6 core entities from the paper's title and abstract:

1. **Large language model** (artifact) - The core technology being surveyed
2. **Agent-based model** (method) - The primary simulation methodology enhanced by LLMs
3. **Complex system** (concept) - The domain being modeled
4. **Emergence** (concept) - Key phenomenon in agent interactions
5. **Intelligent agent** (concept) - The autonomous entities in simulations
6. **Computer simulation** (tool) - The computational technique enabling the simulations

All entities have been:
- ✅ Correctly classified with appropriate entity types
- ✅ Linked to their Wikipedia articles
- ✅ Marked with "uses" relation (since this is a survey using existing technologies/concepts)
- ✅ Provided with relevance explanations
- ✅ Passed validation successfully

Sources:
- [Large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model)
- [Agent-based model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model)
- [Complex system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_system)
- [Emergence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergence)
- [Intelligent agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent)
- [Computer simulation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_simulation)
